positive.review: An ok game... the biggest issue I have is the monetisation, the in game currency is ridiculously expensive for those of us belonging to the African continent. They'd make a killing if they adjusted for certain regions, I can't justify exchanging a week's worth of groceries for bouncing pixels.

For a casual gamer you can spend a lot of time enjoying the game without spending any money.
Some cosmetics can be earned through missions from the free sections of the Battlepass etc.
Some grinds for materials or weapon components can be extremely annoying in later/end level content. We're talking about running the same missions 100s of times to get the neccesary parts or materials.
But you can ignore them, fully upgraded wepons are not a neccessity.
If you can leave that mindset to the hardcore grinders and you'll have an enjoyable time.
Same goes for the cosmetics that cost real money.
Don't expect any kind of organized squad-based combat, unless you bring your friends into the game or missions.
There is no real communications between players in a team albeit not really neccesary.
Apart from maybe when new missions or Bosses drop and and haven't been made easier yet which inevitably happens in a patch a few weeks later.
If you're the kind of player who wants to while away a few hours in a mostly single-player game with occasional random team-based missions then it's totally fine.

< MIXED REVIEW >
The game play is awesome and graphics are stunning. The weapons feel great and mechanics are easy to understand. Although I feel as if the game is lacking more open world. It seems very grindy and repetitive  grinding the same dungeon over and over 10-15 times hoping for good RNG with your loot table. There are a massive amount of upgrade items and when examining the item they do not explain how to use it, so you could be stockpiling items that you could use but have no idea how to. 

In summary it is a great and beautiful shooter with massive potential. It does have a large learning curve and can be repetitive.

Game is alot of fun to spend time in. If you enjoy a casual looter shooter, with beautiful characters and fun gameplay mixed with great shooting mechanics. If you dont take it too hardline then this is a wonderful game to spend some time in and casually grind out things you want, while playing some sexy characters.

On release, I personally believe the developer was still experimenting on design decisions. Obviously, the game has come along way since release and way better with many QoL updates (some of which from the problem they created in the first place).

For those who play games similar as Warframe, Destiny etc. You'll know the basics for this game already but grindier than Warframe. If you're up for it, take it slow and look up some guides for your favourite descendant.
This game is a lot of fun to play. And there's soooo much content and they just keep adding more. The cosmetics are kinda expensive though.

The story is meh.. the "Plot" is thiccc. The gameplay is repetitive.. Its basically warframe with tig ole bitties. 10/10 would spend another 24 hrs straight grinding resources to spend them all in about a minute ( '-')b
Boobie central but the game mechanics are actually very fun. It is like Warframe but less complex and more boob. But still plenty complex in a fun way.

Great game. Really don't have much to say negative other than a suggestion to make drop rates actually match their percentiles. Did the same mission that said 25% drop rate 18 times and got gold at least 13 times

I have played this game a lot over the past year and some change. I love the core gameplay and grindy nature of the game, but I feel like there is a huge disconnect between the developers and the players. They keep changing the way items are grinded or increasing the time to grind them. They also keep releasing content that is super challenging to complete in public lobbies as many players don't have good builds. This means all the damage is done by you or you and one other person. 

I'm hoping they'll learn from their mistakes and use it to help influence new content, but I feel like this is the fourth time I've said that in the past 6 months. Overall the game is good, but the developers could easily kill this game if they don't make some important changes.
Recommended for the gameplay. Monetization is a bit greedy like every other Korean MMO.

My personal likes and dislikes for this game currently are...

+ Fun Third-Person Shooter Gameplay
+ Weapon and Descendant Collecting / Upgrading
+ Everything is earnable except most cosmetics
- Game can get too grindy
- Cosmetics are overpriced
- Some cosmetics are only available for a short window

Thumbs up for now, but just barely.

I love the atmosphere that the game provides. I can get lost in the world and enjoy the story it tells!

Nexon has delivered some engaging titles in the past, and my initial experience with The First Descendant was great. I have already logged a considerable number of hours on the Xbox version.

However, a part of me wishes Nexon's best shooter, Combat Arms, was still around, even though they sold it off.

This particular "shooter looter" feels and looks good. The core issue that may be hindering its potential is its Free-to-Play (F2P) model. As is often the case, free games can become more expensive over time than a single-purchase title.

My recommendation is to enjoy the game while you can. If you start feeling pressured to buy in-game items or resources, consider the experience complete and simply uninstall, as I did previously.

I am currently revisiting the game after a year-long break, though I've noted that recent community reviews are not very promising. I will continue to adjust this review as I play and progress.

As with any live service MMORPG, The First Descendant is an ever evolving experience with each subsequent season update adding more depth to it's ever changing systems. The characters are fun to play as with each sporting their own unique skill sets and play styles. The looter shooter elements while not as wacky with the random stats as most other contemporaries, does have some depth thanks to new systems introduced during the games life cycle such as the adjustment system and weapon core systems. Heck the shear variety of systems layered upon each other definitely means that though you may find a meta build online for a character or weapon, chances are thanks to RNG, your build will still be slightly more unique to just you and I kind of applaud the developers for that.
Had its ups and downs, but it is a pretty good game.
Very fun gameplay, and is fun to grind for hours on end.

I decided to try it...and is free game and looks stuning compared to 90% of paid games. 
Performance is I can talk for PC version... very decent/normal (I play on Ryzen 7+RTX4070Super and 16GB RAM) game runs amazing. 
No matter what other say, all pay content is just cosmetics other is ALL FREE! Story is good, Battle pass is OK, login rewards are on place too, events are here and comunity is friendly. The game is repetitive in one point, monotonous at times, but ...almost every Korean game is like that. At least the characters are VERY beautiful (both males and females) and don't shove Woke/LGBTQ+ in your face now and then like most games today. 
Players simply forget the sad and bitter feeling of paying a lot of euros for all the DLCs, only to have it taken away from you a year later, without you having a choice. There is no paid content in this game that they can take away from you.
In the end...Very good graphics, nice and dynamic gameplay with unique characters which you get for free....I highly recommend it!
The real world prepared me well for this game, i spent half my time on my knees and waiting for someone else to come over

Overall i like the game, does have a lot a of fan service but overall like the expanding storyline, different playstyles and characters.  The game doesn't feel like it'll take yo a lifetime to complete but isn't by far easy. I like that only premium skins are locked behind a paywall, yet everything is grindable and play a actual free to play game.

Downside:

-Kernel level anti cheat installed in order to play

After hundreds of hours in TFD I must review this game and yes, despise all the negative things several individuals can say about TFD, this is a VERY solid game that I recomend to anyone.

As you can see I possess thousands of games (many of these AAA+ in PC and all consoles), so why would I spend my time in this one? is really easy and I will list the reasons:

The GOOD:

Is F2P, if you like it you stay, if not, you can leave 

The game has some impressive visuals, a lot more than supposed AAA games for $80 USD, every single soul who had been in my house while playing this were absolutely surprised by the quality of the graphics in my 98´´ screen 

The gameplay is VERY fun and UNIQUE, there is no other game in the market that offers this wide variety of gameplay and characters to choose; fire, ice, water, toxins, firearms, this game have ALL.

The controls, abilities and weapons feels AMAZING and is compatible with console controllers.

This is basically what we wanted back in 2007-2015... a PvE Gears of War / Halo Sci Fi crossover, where we can fight hordes of Locust / Covenants... I mean "Vulgus" in solo or with a squad, face giant Bosses in fierce spectacular battles.

Yes is a F2P game with In-Game transactions, but is a very fair one and they sell things, skins and costumes that the consumers actually wants... so I gladly pay them for things I love but if you don´t want to spend a dime in the game is possible to have ALL the characters, partners, weapons and vehicles for absolutely FREE and without a lot of effort unlike basically all F2P games out there. Is a Looter Shooter and you need to do missions several times to craft things or pay to get inmediate access to all... is very simple and fair.

Yeah, I will address the elephant in the room... this game has the most BEAUTIFUL female characters in the industry and I am not afraid to say I arrived this game beacuse of that but stayed for everything else. And yes, all the male characters are absolutely handsome as they should be as well, everyone are pleased here. 

The Devs has the guts to sell skins and outfits the consumer ACTUALLY wants, sexy, yet very classy outfits, emotes, spawn animations, etc... and I am glad if they continue to do it. If you are somebody who is offended by female beauty or sexy skins do yourself and everyone a favor and go play other thing.... of course, IF that other thing still has active servers, since most if not all woke propaganda games are doomed from the start.

The collaborations are great, so far we already have Bayonetta and Nier Automata skins and they are stunning. 

I love the Photo Mode and since the graphics are INSANELY GOOD you can create pieces of ART in any place since thei game features all biomas and all of them are beautiful

The Music... this game features several musical compositions and many of them are AWESOME, my respects for whoever made the Luna´s Song since it got released I couldn´t stop hearing it daily at least once. 

Beside that, they managed something rare, they created characters with a SOUL, we CARE about these characters, their story, their motivations, their personality and whatever is happening in this world, they are not just sexy "Barbies" or "Kens", they are characters we can relate or care for, this is something I couldn´t feel since the world that OverWatch built back in 2016 and previously in TF2 or L4D years ago, and I am grateful to experience this again in TFD. Also the cutscenes have such HIGH quality that are EPIC to watch and relive whenever you desire in real time also.

The "End Game"; I had seen several complains about "this game only knows to release skins but no playable content"... let me tell you that is NOT TRUE... I am a player since the Pre-Season and I polay daily and ALWAYS have endless things to do or craft and the Developers are constantly updating the game with new dungeons, bosses, areas, weapons, comrades (Dogs), Vehicles, Modules, etc etc... to keep both, new players and veterans playing.

The Devs are VERY transparent and are always on touch with the community hearing their feedback and updating the game accordingly 

The community is one of the BEST ONES I had seen in my life; most players support each other and are actually helpful which is absolutely RARE in this time and age 

And finally, yeah the game is VERY ALIVE and with a healthy player base, don´t hear any "doom" review from Kotaku, The Gamer, IGN or few others who says the game "is dead" or "will die in X months" just because they HATE any game with beautiful female characters in it; the game already developed a loyal fan base of gamers who enjoys this and keep playing it; I play this daily and always find matches in SECONDS, no matter if I play on day or in the middle of the night and this won´t be gone in a good while I have faith in the future of the game.... and you can see it as well, TFD is always in the Top Games that gained more money every time they release new skins or a new season or a collaboration.

The BAD:

Some characters are getting unexplainable nerfs (like Ines) in a PvE game which is ABSURD and unlike at the start of the game, now all characters are viable but the power creep between some of them is INSULTING specially on PUBLIC matches where the HP of bosses are upgraded to the max... a Serena, Harris, Viessa, Luna or Hailey with a Mediocre build are 1000% times more powerful than Valby for example, specially against Colossus, Bosses or Mini Bosses and needs an URGENT BUFF, and several Descendants are in that bag right now.
  
Having to play over 9000 times the Void Vessel or the Hyper Mega Super Massive Conductor stages to craft a weapon is NOT fun or logic, but YES I clarify these dungeons are right now End Game content and are part of a VERY RECENT tendency which I expect the devs to abandon in further seasons; before that you can still get weapons and characters EASILY.

I have to say it... 90% of the time you WON´T get any damage or performance remotely close to the build you just saw and replicated 1:1 from a YouTuber. Why? I still don´t know why. Is disappointing but we must keep going.   

As the number of Descendants is growing the Devs said they will make LESS universal skins... but I think is just a cheap reason to sell individual skins for more money, still if they are sexy and good looking ones I will keep supporting them. 

The UGLY:

Back in november of 2024, The Devs tried to sell us UGLY Concord-like skins (ugly and covered the full body of the females) and the whole community rejected them immediately, they asked for forgiveness and since then they had been doing "good" skins... so I advice to forgive but NEVER forget and stay alert in case they want to try something funny. 

OVERALL:

I give this game a solid 9/10 for what it is and offers

The First Descendant is a pretty generic 3rd person looter shooter with a lot of elements borrowed from Warframe. 

You play as characters called Descendants, each with their own set of abilities, who must be researched by replaying content until you acquire their research blueprints and requisite crafting materials. Weapons must also be researched in a similar manner. Once you have your desired Descendant and weapons, you can outfit them with mods that increase your stats and apply other enhancements to further increase their stats, often to absurd levels.

The main downside to the game is how easy it is. The devs seem to lack any cohesive direction for the game and are scared of nerfing anything that is too strong after the community revolted when they tried to nerf Ines, who was a new character that could just about kill every enemy in a dungeon on the very first frame after they spawned in. Ultimate Freyna's rework and Serena and Ultimate Luna's releases have done little to inspire confidence that they will turn that ship around.

Coupled with the lack of difficulty is a lack of depth. Unlike Warframe which has like 15 years worth of content to play through, a lot of the new content in TFD feels very shallow. Everything aside from the Colossus bosses, which are a real stand-out feature, is basically just a series of hallways with enemies of varying tankiness depending on the difficulty that rewards you with a box that can be opened for a chance at a research blueprint.

There is no aspirational endgame at this stage like a Raid or really hard dungeon, so the "goal" is basically to just collect characters and weapons until you get bored or new content drops.

The main upside to the game, aside from the Colossus fights, are the girls and basic, but solid gameplay. If you like this kind of game then you can easily be satisfied for a few dozen hours and even longer if you have friends to play with, which can be done completely for free. If you're willing to spend money then there are bunch of buxom ladies just waiting for you to clad in skimpy outfits and admire in photo mode with varying levels of jiggle physics. You should be warned that the prices are pretty high for this type of game: skins run in the range of $10-20 each and the purchasable upgrade materials are a lot more expensive than in Warframe.

If you do end up bouncing off of the game then there's plenty of...ehem...[i]art[/i] of the characters that you can look at. If you know what I mean...
it's a good game by story and graphics  but it's a little bit pay to win . I can give it 8 out of 10

It’s fun for a time. It’s not something I think would hold your attention long & I wouldn’t recommend spending much money until you’re sure it’s for you (mainly cosmetics). Aesthetically, it’s really pretty and the play style is pretty simple in my opinion. Space, boobs, butts and guns w/ special abilities. I feel it’s better to play with friends. Last I played it was super grindy though, so that might be a turn off for some. However, it’s a free shooter so try it out if you’re curious. Won’t cost you anything.
On initial release, this game had a serious drought for content but with a tremendous of developer attention and love, this game is really beginning to come into its' own.

For some reason, the game got me engaged for a longer while than I expected.

Gameplay is very satisfying, yet it may be repetetive at some point (as with many other games of this type). Characters are somewhat diverse and are new are being added every so often. My favourite is Ultimate Luna (music style dps/buffing - I really love the tunes). Weapons are kinda standard, many types with typical features (some excel at AoE, some at burst, some have other unique effects).

If you want an alternative to Warframe or Destiny then The First Descendant can definitely offer you a similar experience that's still different enough to carve out it's own slice of the looter/shooter pie. 

As you no doubt will have seen or heard from others, this game does not shy away from offering plenty of fan service so if that's not something you're fond of seeing in a game then this might not be for you, but for those that do not mind or like it, then you're in for a treat!

The gameplay loop of leveling up and acquiring new gear is addictive and rewarding, nothing feels impossible to achieve or obtain. They also have added a pity system so that you will eventually get what you want after enough attempts, so your time doesn't feel wasted.

I would advise anyone that chooses to get into this game to play it at their own pace, do not rush to the endgame as it will take you a while to get to the endgame. It's a marathon, not a race, enjoy the journey experience the story and immerse yourself in the universe that has been crafted in this game!

Monetisation in this game may be an issue for a number of people as cosmetics are not the cheapest out there, it is a free to play game so it's expected there would be a paid cash shop. Fortunately nothing sold in the shop is pay to win, It's mainly cosmetics with some boosters for exp/gold or resource gain which are time savers, there's no PvP so it's not harming your progression by not buying them.

Overall i would say that this game is worth a shot to at least see if it's for you. I had a blast playing through it, the journey of gearing up, getting better loot, trying out all the characters and their unique abilities, blowing up the screen of enemies. It's a rush and power fantasy. Add to that, you have character customisation and it's a recipe for a lot of hours of fun!

Game is good and a solid looter shooter, that offers strong gunplay and a good way to pass time when bored. However, it's issues makes the game complicated to approach and enjoy for new players and returning players. 

- The Grinding: Despite having many QoL fixes making farming easier, it's still immensely based on your RNG, and you can find yourself farming the same mission for hundreds of times, only for a single thing to drop, which can be draining for many. 

- The Balancing: This is where the game is severely lacking. Every Descendant is unique and enjoyable, but no matter how you build your favorite character, they will always be overshadowed by the same meta characters. Seeing everyone playing the same character is pretty boring and offers no diversity in your gameplay. It will always be the same characters that will just run through everything in every mission, making your entire task to just keep up and follow without doing any actual action.

- Customization and Fan-service: As you can guess, this game is a huge goon fest, with settings going as far as choosing how jiggly female body parts are. You got more female characters than male characters, and skins are just there to make your hot character nearly naked. Sure, if you like playing dress up, it's pretty cool, but yeah. That's it.

- Monetization: The premium currency, Caliber, is overly expensive for no reason at all, making it accessible only for huge whales. Too bad. 

Go for it if you're either horny, or looking for a fun game to turn your brain off and farm. 6.5/10

I'm writing this because the game just went into maintenance for the first time since I started playing it. It was the only way I could pull myself away but I've wanted to leave a review which I don't usually do.

It's an outright travesty for this game to have mixed reviews. It's an absolutely gorgeous AAA quality game that is completely free and in my experience fun as hell.

There is no pay to win in this game. I've been playing less than a week totally free (granted I was no lifing a bit) and I already unlocked ultimate bunny and the dog companion and I am zooming my way into endgame content already with solid gear and build.

Maybe it was more grindy before I started but in it's current form I've enjoyed all the farming I have done and nothing was overly difficult to obtain so far. If you have ever played warframe or runescape or WoW this will not feel like a heavy grind at all. I actually really enjoy the pace I've been unlocking things and I feel super accomplished already and only excited to keep unlocking more descendants and weapons and refining my builds etc.

I haven't spent any money yet but the monetization is pretty much entirely cosmetic. I'm not being kneecapped with any game systems as a no spender. However, I like the game so much if the nier content rolled back around or something else I am interested in I will 100% spend just because I want to support the game and I want it to stay online so I can keep playing it.

Also worth mentioning I have not run into any noticeable bugs or game technical issues, pure smooth sailing for me so far.

I know this sounds like a shill review or something but honestly just excited and having a blast with this game and I definitely see myself playing it for a long time.

I genuinely don't know what the negative reviewers want from the game and don't know what more it can really offer short of the devs coming to your home, cooking you dinner, and offering sexual favors.

I am not normally one to sugarcoat anything, so take my word when I say this may be one of the best F2P looter shooters I've played up to this point. I've reached Mastery Rank 23, unlocked 10 descendants (including 3 Ultimates), 2 of the 3 doggos, and 2 of the vehicles [b]without spending a dime[/b]. The community is also really nice and willing to help if you post in World Chat. [u][b]Obligatory warning: World Chat is full of gooners.[/b][/u]

New gameplay modes and story content are [b]NOT paywalled[/b]. Many items, particularly gameplay-related items (e.g., items that expand module capacity, Fellows, vehicles, etc.) [i]can[/i] be bought with real money, but they can also be earned or crafted in-game. The only things that can be obtained exclusively with paid currency (Caliber) are cosmetics; nothing that impacts progression. 

With that said, if you're like me and decide to go the frugal route, you'll be doing a lot of crafting and farming. Sadly, you're only limited to 8 concurrent items while crafting, but you can also pay to speed up the crafting process. (Don't do it.) 

For farming, I'd recommend picking up Bunny and a doggo and just speedrunning through invasions. The grind in this game is a chore, but at least it's free and you don't have to worry about content being taken away.

negative.review:
There are a lot of great things about the game, but unfortunately too many terrible choices drag the game down so hard. 

Extremely greedy monetization such as the colaboration skins. $80 for all the Nier Automata skins, $35 for the Bayonetta skins, Full battle pass price for a tiny little sword pass that was only around for around a month or two with a quarter of the items in a normal pass. 

A poor obsession with making all new content harder and enemies more spongier than the last content make the game continually less fun and makes more of the characters less viable.

An extreme amount of farming for materials to absurd degrees. Doing anything in the Axion Plains made me groan as you had to complete a mission to get a small chance at receiving a box that had a small chance at containing the item you needed. The newest update includes a mission that only gives you around 5-10 of a mat that's needed for the new Descendant and gun. However, you will need a grand total of 1050 of this material for the character and for a fully ascended gun, meaning you'd need to run the mission over 100 times to get everything you needed. 
This ISN'T an issue of it being a farming game. 
This IS an issue of not balancing drops. It being a farming game doesn't mean that its quality because we got more than 0 mats per run.
Farming in Warframe feels like a minute jog in comparison to this game. 

If you're thinking about trying it, DON'T. In it's current state, it's not worth it.

[h1]The stingiest girl-collecting game[/h1]

I tried this for 20 hours and eventually uninstalled because it was actually LESS generous than a Chinese gacha game which I already wrote a negative review for. Maybe the UI is just terrible so I missed something but regardless, after 20 hours in this product, I still had no character to play with other than the two that were given in the tutorial missions. 

I initially intended to buy one character but then realized that this game uses price obfuscation AND the old trick of selling awkwardly-sized currency bundles that make it impossible to only spend money on the item you want.

[h1]Short version[/h1] 

The grindwall for unlocking new characters is OBSCENE and you can't buy a new character without spending at least $20.

If the story and gameplay were good, these wouldn't spoil the game but neither of those are either good enough to be worth it or bad enough to enjoy ironically. 

Mediocre story, mediocre gameplay, and an economy that is LESS generous than a Chinese gacha game. 

Just play the story mode on HALO, Mass Effect, etc. and steer clear of this product.

[h1]Can't replay beginning of the game.[/h1]

One bafflingly bad design choice which can't even be explained by greed is that you can't replay the opening of the story which not only has the best-looking, cinematic boss battle I saw in 20 hours of playing but ALSO contains the tutorials which you would want to do if you took a break and wanted to get back into the game. 

By not allowing you to repeat the beginning of the game, they actually increased the chances of people quitting rather than getting back on the horse. 

Just why?

[h1]Art syle (or lack therof)[/h1]

Parts of this game actually reminded me of HALO... and that made me sad because then I realized that if this had been made as an honest,, single-player coop game and sold as a complete product, it could have been good.

Unfortunately, they seem to have tried to make a gacha game, then got cold feet about the gambling mechanics, and then decided to make you grind-gamble rather than money gamble (your progress for unlocking things literally is tied to and RNG).

Worse, they apparently felt afraid that if you could unlock things in game for free, too many people would so they made the game incredibly stingy in terms of in-game rewards, even compared to a gacha game.

Why am I bringing this up? It's because the art style is undermined by the same "money-first" approach that ruined the rest of the game. Rather than designing characters and costumes that kind of fit with the setting... and developing the setting, they instead created characters that were obviously intended to appeal to thirsty boys... and they kind of failed at that because they tried too hard.

I happen to think that quite a few real women look good and the fact that lots of men pay them to look that way confirms that I am right. The human-inspired robot dolls in this game however, are just plain weird. 

The faces of most female characters look fine, as I noted myself.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3283902742

HOWEVER, the BODIES of these characters look really off because they are essentially made with anime proportions in a game which generally tries to look photo-realistic. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3284145498

The result isn't attractive so much as grotesque and it gets worse the longer you look at it. I thought "Bunny" was a bit too exaggerated at first but now I just see an alien monster... and I like skinny femme-Shep in the tightest suit possible btw.

If they gave us the option of adjusting how these characters look with regards to proportions, it might not be so bad but of course they don't and since it's a live-service game, you can't fix it with mods either.

[h2] The First Descendant: An Empty Shell [/h2]

I wanted to love this game so badly that I tried my best to find something worth playing, and as result I learned to hate it. With passion.

Zero gameplay value, a laughable plot, character building that is an insult, and overpriced in-game purchases. Let’s break it down.

[h3] Good from a Distance [/h3]
While the game is considered an NSFW Warframe clone, I will judge it independently, as I’ve never tried Warframe. But I have played many third-person shooters, including those with the same “Sexual Content” tag, and I was genuinely surprised. 

This is an expensive project that should easily crush any indie competition, yet it failed miserably. Obviously, character models in revealing outfits is the limit of “Sexual Content” the game allows itself, which was expected. The area where such game must stand out is gameplay and scenario.

But sure, it looks good. The visuals, sound design, and especially the environmental art is top-tier. And that’s what hooks you as you launch the game. The direction of the intro mission and the first cutscene is promising, but it’s the best one in the game, and it only gets worse from there.

[h3] Here for the Plot [/h3]
The campaign suffers from inconsistent storytelling, as if it can’t decide whether it wants to be a funny, joyful adventure or a grim, serious story. In short, you witness how the main cast saves the world through pure luck, as they possess neither the discipline nor the mental health to stay in line and follow orders. Their incompetence will drive you mad more than once if you choose not to skip the repetitive and boring cutscenes. Usually, in such situations, you start rooting for the antagonist, but he is just as stupid and shallow as the main cast.

Most mission require you to listen to ~3 NPCs before starting, and they will repeat each other, adding nothing new. It feels like the writer was either trying to pad the script to justify their pay or believes the player is an idiot who can’t understand the plot the first time.

[h3] So-called Gameplay [/h3]
In the process, you will be surprised at how easy everything is, as mobs and bosses only pose a threat if you go AFK. “Well, it’s probably just the overextended tutorial; the main gameplay is the Hard Difficulty unlocked after beating the campaign,” you might think. Nope. This IS the core gameplay. 

First, no skill or effort is required. Your level and equipment are all you need, and if your character and build are right, you can clear any level or boss by clicking ONE button. If you’re failing, you’re probably under-leveled, as there is no way to compensate for stats with personal skill.

Skill, you see, is painfully irrelevant here. We have an evade roll with no i-frames, so it’s a dash at best. We have no parry, and the block here is miserable: your character stands there, holding their sword awkwardly, and it just mitigates incoming damage a bit. There isn’t even animation of intercepting incoming hits; IT JUST STANDS. Imagine a AA-game losing in terms of animations and gameplay value to 1$ cash-grab porn games where gameplay is added only for show.

Sometimes, to prolong your way to endgame content, game prepared a difficulty spikes for ya. You might wonder: what problems could it be if I said the game is easy? The HP multiplier. The only way the devs know to make it harder. The same mobs with the same models just get x10, x100, x1000 HP, and that’s just fine for TFD. It’s not actually difficult; it’s just a test of your DPS.

[h3] The Building is on Fire [/h3]
Character building, then? That’s logical - if this RPG has no skill value, it probably has a deep and complex leveling and enchantment system. Yes, it has, and first, it’s truly complex, maybe over-complicated, and second: HALF OF IT USELESS.

It will take hours to tens of hours to grind for a set of items with the right stats, as RNG decides how good a dropped item is. But that’s not a problem for some people; I love good ‘ol grind myself. The thing is, the game designers have no idea what they are doing. Some characters have a such a great advantage over others that no amount of grinding will ever equalize them. You will spend hours grinding the perfect setup for a character you like and still be a deadweight in a dungeon, while broken characters with no grind will annihilate everything in seconds.  The most infamous build to one-shot the top boss doesn’t include a Reactor or External Components - literally half of the character build. The devs don’t care – they never fix what’s broken, only adding even more broken characters to the game.

[h3] Forced Multiplayer [/h3]
Yeah, by the way, there is multiplayer. For whatever reason. You might think this IS a multiplayer game, but think again. The point is that everything easier and more comfortable solo because the more participants there are, the more HP enemies have. If a player has problems with a content and goes online, they will only find another poor soul who also has problems. As a result, they will end up suffering together, as content only becomes harder. This is straight illogical - the more help you get the harder it becomes. 

The best way to beat the game is to play privately, but you will still wait for the matchmaking server search. Modern classic: a single-player game requiring an internet connection. 
 
The maximum number of players in a location is 4 (expt for 1 boss), so it’s hardly MMO, but in the hub, there are 16+ characters at once because the devs understand priorities: skin and animations show-off are more important for them than gameplay.

[h3] The Game from Brave Creators [/h3]
After all this, the devs DARE to charge the price of a AAA-game per skin in First Descendant. Gods, that’s bold. But any cheap NSFW game on UE4+ has models of similar quality without charging you the price of a full game, not to mention they will likely feature actual sexual content like H-scenes.

At the end of the day, there is literally no reason to even start playing TFD, and there are many things that deserve your money and what’s more important - your time - more than this.

You want a good solo/co-op third-person shooter? Try Remnant or Helldivers. You want a true NSFW game with both gameplay and good H-scenes? Try Project Werewulf.

Do yourself a favor and skip Firs Descendant. Good looks are all it’s got.

The latest patches have added a lot of friction to the game, and it’s no longer enjoyable. Farming is expected, but with every update they add another bleak map that you have to run a hundred times just to get one item you probably don’t even need. For the last three seasons, the game has basically forced players to use Serena because everything else feels weak in comparison.

They introduced some “rebalancing,” but it’s nowhere near enough. The so-called “new” content still has spongy bosses that require heavily optimized builds, and the only real tankiness still comes from Serena.

They also added swords, and they’re a complete mess. Swords require ammo and even share ammo with rocket launchers, which makes no sense. Ammo-generation skills don’t work while a sword is equipped, and heavy attacks often swing in random directions instead of toward the targeted boss.

Players used to complain that new weapons and descendants were overpowered; now the new stuff isn’t even worth farming, and Serena remains OP. It feels like the devs have gotten lazy and are only focused on what new skin they can sell next, forgetting that players need fun, engaging content before they’ll want to spend money on cosmetics.

The First Descendant feels like one of those games that should be great on paper..... big bosses, flashy abilities, sci-fi loot, shiny Unreal Engine visuals.... but the moment you start playing properly, the cracks show faster than you’d expect.

The gunplay is serviceable, but it rarely feels impactful. Enemies soak bullets like they’re being paid to waste your time, and boss fights often feel more like repeating the same patterns than anything truly exciting. The abilities look impressive, sure, but the actual feel of them is hit-and-miss — some are fun, others might as well be decorative.

What drags the whole thing down is the grind. And I mean the grind.
Every upgrade, every piece of gear, every unlock feels buried behind layers of materials, timers, and currencies. Instead of wanting to progress, you start questioning why everything requires a shopping list longer than your arm.

Performance is another headache. Stutters, weird lag spikes, and visual bugs pop up often enough to remind you the game isn’t quite as polished as it pretends to be. Matchmaking can also be inconsistent, leaving you stuck waiting around in what’s supposed to be a fast-paced co-op looter shooter.

There is potential here ...the world looks good, some Descendants are stylish, and the foundation could evolve into something solid. But in its current state, it feels more like a flashy demo wrapped in excessive grinding and inconsistent gameplay.

If you enjoy looter shooters and don’t mind a heavy grind wall, you might squeeze some fun out of it.
But if you’re after something tight, polished, and rewarding… this probably isn’t the one

I played The First Descendant since the beta and ended up putting over 100 hours into the full release, even going as far as platinum-ing it on PS5. At launch it really felt like a fresh, exciting looter shooter — but the more I played, the more the game’s biggest issues became impossible to ignore.
-
Almost everything is heavily time-gated. Crafting characters and gear can take entire days, and during the last week I was logging in only to craft the same thing every single day. Unlocking new characters also requires farming the same missions in a loop over and over just to get the materials you need.
-
On top of that, a few trophies were buggy for me, which made the experience even more frustrating. And while I know it’s a free-to-play game, the monetization feels very aggressive: you can skip crafting timers with money, and some bundles or character-related purchases can get quite expensive depending on the currency packs offered.
-
If you enjoy grind-heavy games with long crafting timers, you might still have fun — the core gameplay isn’t bad at all. But personally, between the time gates, repetitive loops, bugs, and the overall push toward spending, I lost interest. There are better options out there in this genre.

I have been playing this game for quite a while (it was also the first looter shooter I've played), it was pretty fun at first but as of today I have uninstalled due to the forced arbitration they just put out and MANY other issues (see below). 

My problems with the game in no particular order-
- Extremely unstable on PC. When I first started, the game ran fairly well, only had some stuttering when there were alot of explosions going on (turned those off). However with each "update" the stuttering got progressively worse & worse as well as affecting areas where previously there had been none. Loading into instances also started taking longer and longer and lon...Well you get the point.

-Making the game more "solo only". The devs have been putting more solo instances in the game and the main story as well as making the solo give better/more rewards. I picked the game up because it looked like dungeon focus type that you would run with other players, working together to defeat the big baddies and all their minions. Take that away (or make it so loot drops in solo makes multi undesirable) and you you drive off folks like me that LOVE to run with other people. To give an example the absolute most fun I had was in a 400% dungeon with myself as Bunny (mob deleter), Luna (buffer), Freyna (mob deleter) and Gley (boss deleter), working together, we cleared in an insanely short time and I've not seen a better time since lol.

-Balence. Most of the descendants are useless unless you're a masochist and if it's timed, you end up actually being a DETRIMENT because you won't be doing enough damage to beat the timer. In my opinion ALL the descendants should be usable (with some being more desirable against elemental bosses of course) but because it's easier to go "Here's the 2-3 meta, have fun" that's what the devs go with (oh and the meta is ALWAYS female, more on that later). I would LOVE to play Ajax but I'm unwilling to be essentially dead weight to my team so am "forced" into meta.

Weapons- Suffer from the same problem as descendants with only a couple being good, one or two others having niche use & the rest basically useless.

Skins- Hooboy where to start here? Hmm let's going with price first- far, FAR too expensive! Look I completely get the it's a FTP game and they DO need to make money both to keep the game going and to add to the game but good grief as much as $60 for a SINGLE skin?! Miss me with that nonsense. Then there's the whole ish tons of female skins (to put on the devs metas), most of which are just c00mer bait to siphon money from lonely males and only a few skins for male descendants, many of which don't even look good. Where's my itty-bitty postage stamp speedo for men and Halo-esce body armor for women dagnabbit!?

Loot drops- RNG on top of RNG=Not fun. So originally you had to hope you got an amorphous material from your targeted mission/dungeon then you had to spend it and hope you got loot you needed, now you hope you get a loot box (very small chance), open it and hope you get the piece you need. In my opinion, there should be a vendor that you could trade parts you have for those you need for example let's say I have an ult Gley blueprint and I already have Gley. Well then I could trade that blueprint for say an ult Luna blueprint, I personally would set it up so there were some restrictions like only weapon for weapon, regular descendant for reg ect. but tradable non the less.

Also pertaining to loot is the rerolling of stats, I do NOT find enjoyable burning through massive amounts of materials & gold but ending up with nothing to show for it because the rerolls were all WORSE then what was already on the weapon. If they made it so that rerolls were never worse then what you had it would make it more enjoyable. To give an example suppose I have 5% crit chance on a gun, I get lucky and get another crit chance on reroll it would always be 6% or better never 5 or lower. I would still have to fight with getting rolls I DIDN'T want (say bonus damage to faction) but when getting what I did, I would be guaranteed to get least a small upgrade.

Dyes- While I personally don't mind too much that they are one-time use, I DON'T like that many of them don't look good on the models (this is for both hair & gear), you should be able to use more then black & white and have it look good. The colors don't even match the thumbnail most of the time. And some of the dye channels are highly questionable i.e the tiniest lil piece you have to squint to see.

Combat- They have been turning things into absolute bullet sponges, which I don't find fun at all (admittedly that could be my fruit fly on crack attention span lol).

All in all I feel this game had a lot of potential that the devs have fumbled (and continue to), unfortunate.

It's becoming increasingly clear that the developers are unsure which direction this game should take — is it a looter-shooter, a pure gunplay experience, a skill-based game with guns as mere stat sticks, or a “gooner game” because of the overly sexualized skins they're selling?

Every time I log into the main city, I’m greeted by half-naked characters showing off their asses in bikini skins. Content updates seem targeted more at new players. For day-one veterans, there's practically no meaningful content and little variety, unless you're into min-maxing or chasing leaderboard ranks.

The company's greed is also showing through the latest skins and the previous “Sword Pass” they're selling. As a day-one player, I completed the latest content update on November 6, 2025, in just four days, but I don't care about Hive copies. There's still no real balance among descendants — you only ever need one, the overpowered Serena.

Material grinding is awful. The new material is locked behind a single dungeon, dropping only 4–9 pieces per run. You need around 300 for the Harris character and 750 for the new Hive Master weapon — a total of 1,050 pieces.

The developers keep repeating the same cycle: new content, community feedback, apologies, and the same mistakes. No, no, no — that’s enough.

Over a year since launch, the community now reflects the state of the game itself — fractured, fatigued, and cynical. Most of the veteran players who cared about balance and design have long left. What remains is a mix of people staying for the cosmetics, a few defenders trying to justify the direction, and the rest who linger out of habit or irony.

Discussion spaces are filled with sarcasm, “copium” jokes, and recycled complaints that never lead anywhere. Constructive criticism is gone; anyone trying to stay positive is instantly dismissed. It’s no longer a passionate fanbase — just survivors of disappointment.

The burnout is real, both in gameplay and community spirit. At this point, the Discord feels less like a place for feedback and more like a post-mortem chatroom for what the game could’ve been.

For me, at the current state of the game, it's time to take another break.

So I saw this was free to play and gave it a whirl. It's a strange mix of a teenage boy's wet dream, Destiny 2, Halo and a few other bits thrown in. The gross over-sexualisation of the female characters with their hilariously appalling jelly breasts and lurid costumes distracts from reasonably solid gameplay, great visuals and well animated characters. 

The dialogue and plot is pretty laboured and in great Destiny 2 fashion, apparently everyone, even the bad guys can talk on the same radio and discuss their plans. There's even the same evil villain diabolical laugh. 

Some bad points - again, from Destiny, bullet sponge bosses that you have to repeat the same sequence of weakening three times to defeat. The monetisation is dreadful, sucking the life and soul out of a game that could be amazing - the same thing that ruined D2 and a lot of other games. I get that the game studio is in business to make money and it costs a lot of money to create and run a game like this, but there's better ways of funding your product. 

But the worse thing about this game is that teenage wet dream - the unfiltered and unmoderated chat is a toxic mess of misogyny, abuse and sexual comments - it's well worth switching off altogether as the game pulls in the worst of male society. 

So I can't recommend it and if they ever charge for the game you'd be a fool to buy it or in it's current form, spend any money on it, unless you're a teenage boy or basement dweller.

Unfortunately it just feels like the game is bullying you into spending money to get ANYTHING you want.
